Message.Title: Global Unemployment to Surge Past 2009 Record World Unemployment to Hit Record High in 2013
Message.Msg: World unemployment could top record levels this year and continue rising until 2017, the International Labour Organization (ILO) said on Tuesday in its annual employment report. 2009 currently stands as the worst recorded year for world unemployment, with 198 million people across the globe without work. In its 2013 Global Employment Trends report, the ILO forecasts unemployment numbers will rise by 5.1 million in 2013 to reach 202 million, topping 2009's record. Global Unemployment to Surge Past 2009 Record World Unemployment to Hit Record High in 2013

Message.Title: President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression
Message.Msg: European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression Feb 10, 2013 Schulz says EU on path to depression: report European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression, according to an interview with Saturday's edition of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. "[The E.U.] is on a path to a depression, apathy, a mood of not caring. That's dangerous, as that mood superimposes the great successes of the E.U., for which it recently won the Nobel Peace Prize," Mr. Schulz is quoted as saying.

Message.Title: One potential big-win market- Bac
Message.Msg: The housing market is continuing to rise, and with yesterday's news that mortgage delinquencies are falling, there's plenty of room for relevant stocks to rise as well. In the index this morning, financial stocks were mixed, with Bank of America (NYSE: BAC ) up and JPMorgan down. Bank of America had a huge day yesterday, with a 3.5% gain, and opened almost 1% higher today. Though it's back to the level of its previous close, this is a huge win for B of A investors, who have been waiting a long time for vindication.

Message.Title: Judge dismisses ATM fee collusion lawsuits
Message.Msg: A federal judge has dismissed antitrust lawsuits accusing Visa Inc, MasterCard Inc, Bank of America Corp, JPMorgan Chase & Co and Wells Fargo & Co of conspiring to fix automated teller machine fees. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson in Washington, D.C., said the plaintiffs failed to present enough facts to show they were injured, or that there was an actual agreement or conspiracy to charge excessive fees. Among the plaintiffs in the lawsuits were individual consumers as well as the National ATM Council, which represents independent non-bank ATM operators.

Topic.Title: WOW- Texas has 8 billion budget surpus..........on top of 10 billion rainy day fund..........no raise in TAXES....NO state TAX

Message.Msg: I think people like you went out and bought something that they thought was going to make them rich, despite not having the money to pay for it. Without that demand, no housing bubble would exist. The enabling factor was a congress with key bullying members (Dodd/Frank/Schumer) who, like McCarthy with communists, saw and named a racist in every congressman & senator who would not agree to relax lending standards via the GSEs for low-income people, thus ensuring a calamitous outcome. Any debate to the contrary is pure nonsense. These men, using the regulators as their executioners, forced banks into the briar patch, and the banks did the best they could to offload the risk. Nobody is innocent, but there are a few who are far more guilty than the others, and the Gingrich congress was not in that midst. You are simply trying to shift blame, and you are doing an immensely poor job of it. Try another profession, you aren't cut out for politics, banking, or debate. I'd suggest marketing, as it fits your propagandist style.
